item.title: Using wheelie bins and cones to reserve parking space, 25th January
item.description:
Reserving car park space using bins and traffic cones. The road has free on-street parking- no one has delegated spaces. The owner has also left a note on my car asking me to use “all available space” when I parked near his bins. All of this is unacceptable and makes the street a really passive aggressive place to be.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Speranza Street, Plumstead
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Rubbish scattered around the building entrance, 25th January
item.description:
Once again, the area in front of quested court 1-10 is full of rubbish. Some in bags near the bins (5 days before collection), some just scattered around including newspapers and clothes.
Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Brett Road, Hackney, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: There are 2 Rools Royces parked in Dulwich Village. They have been parked in the same place for months, 25th January
item.description:
These cars are covered in canvas protection covers. The owner clearly does not want to move them at the moment. They are causing a nuisance as they are preventing people form parking in their spaces. This is detrimental to our local shops and businesses.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Dulwich Village, Dulwich Village, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Wooden pallets and furniture on the pavement, 25th January

item.title: Wondering why street tree was cut down in December?, 25th January
item.description:
Hallo, I live in Kings Hall Road (no. 180). I was away for the first two weeks in December 2025, and when I came back I found that two large, beautiful street trees near my house had been cut down. One was more or less outside number 198 (if memory serves it was some kind of unusual oak), and the other was on the other side of the road, a bit further towards Bridge Road (perhaps near no. 185 or similar; possibly a London plane tree, or another oak). Please could you explain what happened, and why? The trees did not show any outward sign of disease, I think (I do look at all of them closely and regularly!) Thank you.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Kings Hall Road, New Beckenham, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet
